user_prompt: From 'If I charge my phone, it will have power' can we infer 'If I charge my phone and it has a dead battery, it will have power'?
system_prompt:
When evaluating conditional statements, remember that real-world conditionals often have implicit background assumptions and normal conditions built in. Don't apply formal logical rules mechanically without considering whether additional conditions in the antecedent might contradict these implicit assumptions.

After considering these factors, write 'Answer: ' followed by only 'yes' or 'no' and nothing else.

responses.content:
Let me work through this carefully.

The original statement is: "If I charge my phone, it will have power" (If P, then Q)

The proposed inference is: "If I charge my phone AND it has a dead battery, it will have power" (If P∧R, then Q)

From a formal logic perspective, this inference seems valid: if P→Q is true, then (P∧R)→Q should also be true, since whenever P is true (which includes cases where P∧R is true), Q follows.

However, the key issue here involves implicit background assumptions. The original conditional "If I charge my phone, it will have power" carries an implicit assumption that the phone is in normal working condition. A "dead battery" suggests the battery itself is defective or permanently damaged—not just depleted.

If the battery is truly dead (broken, not just uncharged), then charging it might not restore power. This contradicts the implicit normal-condition assumption embedded in the original statement.

The proposed inference adds a condition ("has a dead battery") that violates the background assumptions necessary for the original conditional to hold true. We cannot validly infer a conditional that introduces a condition contradicting the implicit premises of the original statement.

Answer: no
